;;在美国空军于 2023 年 3 月 7 日发布的这张照片中，B-21 袭击者向美国空军揭幕2022 年 12 月 2 日在加利福尼亚州帕姆代尔举行的仪式上公开。
;

;负责就美国核武器战略提供建议的国会高级别委员会的 12 名成员中，有 9 名与承包商有直接的财务关系，这些承包商《卫报》和《负责任的治国之道》可以透露，他们将受益于报告的建议，或者受雇于从武器制造商那里获得大量资金的智囊团。

;

;虽然 ;​​美国战略态势国会委员会;（CCSPUS）声称建议采取措施避免核冲突，但它没有透露自己与武器的潜在利益冲突工业界在其最终报告或华盛顿智囊团的推介活动中。

;

;美国很快将面临“两个国家（中国和俄罗斯）拥有与我们同等核武库的世界”，警告说委员会的最终;报告;，发布于十月中旬。 “此外，”报告指出，“与这两个核国家发生冲突的风险正在增加。这是美国尚未做好准备的生存挑战。”

;

;根据 CCSPUS 的说法，这种潜在的世界末日场景要求美国“对美国核能力的态势——规模——进行必要的调整。和/或组成”，这一政策转变将把数十亿纳税人的钱引向五角大楼和核武器承包商。

;
;
;

;当业界正在购买时，我们无法就我们的安全做出严肃的决定通过智库和委员的影响力

;
; ;国际废除核武器运动的苏西·斯奈德;
;
;
;

;“我们一直以来核武器工业正在购买影响力，这意味着当该行业通过歪曲辩论的智囊团和委员购买影响力时，我们无法就我们的安全做出严肃的决定。” ://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/nov/10/nuclear-disarmament-activists-putin-ukraine">;国际废除核武器运动;。

;

;“而不是我们正在争论我们需要什么工具和材料来保证自己的安全，”她补充道，“我们正在争论哪家公司应该获得合同。这并不能让美国人民或世界上任何其他人的安全。”

;

;CCSPUS 是两年前通过年度国防政策;法案;，委员会的利益冲突是;从一开始就很明显;。但《卫报》和《负责任的治国之道》的分析发现，该委员会与武器工业之间存在着深厚的联系。

;

;CCSPUS 中最知名的成员是其副主席乔恩·凯尔 (Jon Kyl)，他曾担任亚利桑那州参议员从1995年到2013年，以及约翰·麦凯恩去世后的2018年。虽然这包含在委员会报告的他的传记中，但遗漏的是他最近的;就业; 担任 Covington & 律师事务所高级顾问Burling 的游说客户;名单;包括多个五角大楼承包商，这些承包商将从中受益委员会的建议。

;

;2017 年，Kyl 个人;注册;为;诺斯罗普游说格鲁曼公司生产 B-21 核轰炸机;，委员会建议美国应购买更多数量的飞机，这会让纳税人付出近;每人 7 亿美元;。

;

;凯尔没有回应关于他在 Covington & 的就业状况的问题Burling，但这位前参议员在该公司网站上被列为“高级顾问”，至少持续到 2022 年 12 月 1 日，即 CCSPUS 委员选举;2022 年 3 月宣布; .

; ;

;另一位委员富兰克林·米勒 (Franklin Miller) 是商业咨询公司斯考克罗夫特集团 (Scowcroft Group) 的负责人，该公司将米勒描述为在“核威慑”方面拥有专业知识，并承认其在武器领域的工作。

;

;“斯考克罗夫特集团成功为欧洲国防领导者提供了战略收购机会的咨询服务，”该咨询公司在其;被任命;为 C3 AI 首席执行官特别顾问，C3 AI 是一家;拥有;与国防部众多机构合作的人工智能公司。 2022 年 6 月，海腾被;任命;为蓝色起源基金会执行董事，该基金会称为俱乐部未来，并担任蓝色起源高级领导层的战略顾问。 Blue Origin 由亚马逊创始人 Jeff Bezos 全资拥有，并直接与 ;美国国家航空航天局;（美国宇航局），;空军;和;太空部队;与太空发射相关的能力。

;

;考虑到 CCSPUS 报告一再提出改善和投资太空和人工智能能力，海顿与这些公司的关系值得注意。具体来说，;报告;建议美国“紧急部署更具弹性的太空架构”，并采取措施确保其“处于新兴技术的前沿——例如大数据分析、量子计算和人工智能（AI）”。

;

;海顿没有回应置评请求。

;

;CCSPUS 还包括智库学者，他们的雇主从军火工业获得大量资金。两名委员会成员在哈德逊研究所工作，根据其最新的年度;报告;，2022 年从五角大楼承包商收到超过 50 万美元。其中包括来自五角大楼一些顶级承包商的六位数捐款，包括洛克希德·马丁公司、诺斯罗普·格鲁曼公司和 BAE Systems。

;

;周一， 10 月 23 日，哈德逊研究所举办了一次;活动;，以强调CCSPUS 的报告中包括两名担任委员的哈德逊研究所员工。这次活动毫不掩饰地宣传了报告中的建议，这对哈德逊的资助者来说将是一笔意外之财。该活动的登陆页面上有一张 B-21 隐形轰炸机的照片，该委员会报告中也使用了同一张照片，该报告还建议修改美国战略核态势，以“增加 B-21 轰炸机和加油机的计划数量， ”。

;

;活动中和报告中都没有指出该飞机的制造商诺斯罗普·格鲁曼公司是哈德逊研究所的最高捐助者，捐款超过 100,000 美元;2022 年;。

; ;

;担任委员的哈德逊研究所工作人员没有回应置评请求。

;

;另一位委员马修·克罗尼格 (Matthew Kroenig) 是大西洋理事会 (Atlantic Council) 的副主席，该理事会是华盛顿特区著名的智库，根据该组织最新的;年度报告;，由几家五角大楼顶级承包商资助，包括洛克希德·马丁公司、诺斯罗普·格鲁曼公司、雷神公司（现为RTX）、通用电气公司原子能公司、萨博公司和通用汽车防务公司。大西洋理事会每年还直接从国防部获得超过 1 美元的资金，从能源部获得 250,000 至 499,999 美元的资金，帮助管理国家的核武库。

;

;这些表面上的利益冲突并未被提及。在 CCSPUS 报告中或在大西洋理事会;活动;中宣传该报告并以哈德逊研究所和委员会使用的 B-21 的同一张照片。

;

;克罗尼格没有回应置评请求。

;

;即使是那些职业生涯中曾担任过显着职位的委员批评核武器的公司最近与从核武器和常规武器工业中获利的公司建立了联系。

;

;委员丽莎·戈登-哈格蒂 (Lisa Gordon-Hagerty) 多年来一直在美国核武器政策的顶峰工作，包括在国家安全委员会、美国众议院和能源部。她还是美国科学家联合会的主任，这是一个非营利组织;因倡导全球核武器削减。在加入该委员会之前，她的最后一个政府职位是担任国家核安全局（NNSA）局长，负责核科学的军事应用。据称，她于 2020 年辞去了该职务; 在与能源部长发生激烈分歧后，能源部长试图削减国家核安全局的资金。

;

;虽然委员会报告中提到了她的大部分职业生涯，但没有提及的是，戈登-哈格蒂也曾被利用她的核专业知识赚钱。离开 NNSA 后，她于 2021 年加入董事会并成为董事。西屋政府服务公司的战略计划，该公司是一家核武器承包商，已;支付;数亿美元的工作费用与国防部和能源部合作。

;

;戈登-哈格蒂没有回应置评请求。

;

;与戈登-哈格蒂一样，专员莱昂诺·托梅罗 (Leonor Tomero) 在最高级别的核武器政策。根据她在委员会;报告中的简历;，她曾担任负责核与导弹防御政策的副助理国防部长，并在众议院武装部队委员会担任顾问和战略力量小组委员会工作人员领导职务十多年，其职责包括建立美国太空部队，核武器、核不扩散、核清理、军备控制和导弹防御。

;

;在政府之外，托梅罗曾担任军备控制和不扩散中心的核不扩散主任，该组织拥有 ;重复; ;呼吁;削减美国核武器库。托梅罗还是宜居世界委员会的董事会成员，该委员会明确;声明;其目标是消除核武器。

; <然而，9 月份，托梅罗成为 JA Green & Co. 的政府关系副总裁。 Company，一家游说公司，其客户;名单;包括许多军事承包商，如果 CCSPUS 的建议被采纳，这些承包商的收入可能会猛增。例如，SpaceX 每三个月向 JA Green 支付 50,000 美元的 ;与“与国家安全太空发射相关的问题”相关的游说;——可能会从委员会的建议中受益匪浅，该建议是“美国紧急部署更具弹性的太空架构，并采取包括进攻性和防御性要素的战略，以确保美国进入太空并在太空开展业务”。

;

;“JA Green & 没有客户”。公司试图以任何方式影响委员会的工作或委员会的建议，”JA Green 总裁 Jeffrey A Green 在一封电子邮件中表示。 “我们遵守所有适用的道德规则，不存在利益冲突。”

;

;CCSPUS 未披露委员们的经济利益与其最终报告中提出的政策建议之间的潜在利益冲突在其最终报告中或在任何强调其调查结果的公开活动中。

;

;虽然许多委员没有回应置评请求，但该委员会的执行董事 William A Chambers 代表 CCSPUS 发表了一份声明，并且

;

;“[委员会]的成员是由国会议员根据他们在政府服务、执法、武装部队、法律等​​专业领域的国家认可度和丰富的经验来选择和任命的。 、公共管理、情报收集、商业或外交事务，”钱伯斯写道。 “在他们开始履行专员职责之前，他们接受了有关管理国会实体的道德规则的指导，并被要求遵守参议院道德特别委员会和众议院道德委员会制定的规则。 ”

;

;钱伯斯没有回应索要道德规则副本的请求。

;

;但潜在利益冲突的不透明性让一些专家对 CCSPUS 的建议提出质疑。

;国际废除核武器运动的斯奈德表示：“关于什么是安全、安全在多大程度上依赖于透明度，存在着激烈的争论，特别是在核武器方面，人们呼吁提高透明度。” 。 “他们要求照亮中国、朝鲜和伊朗的光芒，也需要照亮他们自己的决策。”

; Sat, 11 Nov 2023 04:52:01 +0800 Letters containing fentanyl sent to several US states’ election officeshttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/nov/10/election-offices-letters-fentanyl-usps
;;2023-11-10T14:09:50Z;
;
;;周三，紧急和执法机构对华盛顿州伦顿金县选举办公室可能出现的危险情况做出反应，2023 年 11 月 8 日。周三，华盛顿州的四个县选举办公室在工作人员正在处理周二选举的选票时，收到了装有可疑粉末的信封（其中两个经现场测试芬太尼呈阳性），随后进行了疏散。
;

;美国执法官员正在寻找向至少五个州的选举办公室发送含有可疑物质的信件的责任人，一些选举官员称其行为为“恐怖主义”。

;

;佐治亚州的选举办公室、内华达州、加利福尼亚州、俄勒冈州和华盛顿州都收到了这些信件，其中四封含有致命药物芬太尼，;美联社报道;。有些信件在到达之前就被截获了。联邦调查局和美国邮政局正在调查。

;
;

;;相关：;;被指控攻击保罗·佩洛西的男子吸收了阴谋论，审判听取了;

;
;

;在华盛顿斯卡吉特、斯波坎、皮尔斯和金（其中包括西雅图）四个县的选举办公室在工作人员清点周二选举的选票时被疏散。其中两封信的芬太尼检测呈阳性。华盛顿州民主党国务卿史蒂夫·霍布斯;在信中说道; 是“威胁我们选举的恐怖主义行为”。

;

;在佐治亚州，一封信被寄往富尔顿县，那里是唐纳德·特朗普许多毫无根据的攻击的目标。佐治亚州国务卿、共和党人布拉德·拉芬斯伯格在周四的新闻发布会上表示，这些信件是;“国内恐怖主义”;。

;

;这一事件是突显自 2020 年选举以来选举官员面临的威胁和骚扰严重程度的最新事件。他们中的许多人选择离开这个行业，这引发了人们的担忧，即选举办公室将出现经验真空，而这些真空可能会由新手或选举怀疑论者填补，从而在 2024 年产生错误和延误。

;

;12%的选举官员在 2020 年大选后开始工作，另有 11% 的人表示他们可能在 2024 年之前离职。选举官员显示在安全威胁中人员流动​​率很高以及布伦南司法中心的四月份调查;。 45% 的选举官员表示，他们在明年的总统选举之前担心其他选举官员的安全。

;

;皮尔斯县的县审计员琳达·法默 (Linda Farmer) 发布了她办公室的这封信的图片已收到。据美联社报道，上面写着“立即结束选举”，并包含反法西斯符号、五角星和进步旗帜。 “停止向他们没有的权利授予权力。信中写道：“我们现在负责，不再需要他们了。”该设施的。法默说，她后来被告知信中所含的物质是小苏打。

;

;俄勒冈州国务卿办公室还告诉《华盛顿邮报》，莱恩县（包括尤金市）的选举办公室，已收到一封信，但这不会影响完成选举。

;

;加州州务卿雪莉·韦伯 (Shirley Weber)，民主党人，;确认信件已被截获，调查正在进行中。她在一份声明中表示：“联邦和州当局正在调查这一事件，但尚未证实这些信封含有任何有毒物质。”

;

;内华达州民主党国务卿思科·阿吉拉尔 ;还在一份声明中表示;他的办公室知道发送给办公室的信件那里。

;

;研究人员发现，意外接触芬太尼造成伤害的风险很低。

;

;“这不是什么新鲜事 - 这只是一种不同的策略，”David Becker，选举创新中心的选举管理专家研究，;告诉华盛顿发布;。 “这只是代表了选举官员的难度。”

; Sat, 11 Nov 2023 04:52:01 +0800 Rishi Sunak faces Tory civil war as he holds off sacking Suella Bravermanhttps://www.theguardian.com/politics/2023/nov/10/rishi-sunak-faces-tory-civil-war-holds-off-sacking-suella-braverman

;;Suella Braverman 和 Rishi Sunak 上个月排名第 10 位
;

;Rishi Sunak 正面临内战保守党内政大臣对内政大臣的未来表示不满，因为内政大臣称警方在停战日允许亲巴勒斯坦游行存在偏见，因此没有解雇她。

;

; ;周六，有史以来最大规模的大规模抗议活动;，苏埃拉·布雷弗曼 (Suella Braverman) 的盟友声称，超过 50 名保守党议员正在为帮助她保住工作而奋斗。

;

;其中一些议员来自极右翼保守党团体被贴上“五个家庭”标签的人 - 还指责首席党鞭西蒙·哈特策划了除掉她的阴谋。

;

;另一方面，温和派保守党议员对布雷弗曼之前煽动紧张局势感到愤怒苏纳克正在考虑布雷弗曼作为内政大臣的未来，因为她向唐宁街提出了挑战，提交了向《泰晤士报》发表有争议的文章;不做任何修改; 它要求的。

;

;自那以后，内政大臣一直保持沉默，但在周五会见了大都会专员马克·罗利爵士，并发表了一份支持警方的声明，显然是为了平息愤怒并留在岗位上。

;

;一位与布雷弗曼关系密切的消息人士表示：“专员概述了继续努力维持公共秩序、确保遵守法律并维护参与者、警察和公众安全的计划.

;

;“内政大臣强调，在复杂且充满挑战的局势中，她全力支持警方，并表示相信任何犯罪行为都将得到强有力的处理。”

;

;自哈马斯以来10 月 7 日引发了与以色列的战争，导致 1,400 人死亡并劫持了约 240 名人质，伦敦和英国各地举行了一系列游行，示威者多达 100,000 人。抗议者一直呼吁停火，巴勒斯坦官员称加沙已有一万多人丧生。游行基本上是和平的，但也有一些人因煽动种族仇恨而被捕。

;

;苏纳克还表示，警方向他保证，他们“正在采取一切措施，确保纪念活动免受任何抗议活动的影响” ”。

;

;A burned-out vehicle found nearby is believed to be tied to the shooting.

;

;Officers confirmed Uppal was known to police and had previously been shot and wounded in an attack at a pizza restaurant in 2021. ;

;Autopsies on Uppal and his son have been scheduled for early next week.

;

;“With a heavy heart, I contemplate how it's conceivable for a child to be killed in such a tragic manner like this,” Alberta's premier, Danielle Smith, said in a statement. “Like many of you, I am concerned with the rise in gun violence in our neighbourhoods.”

;Edmonton, like other metropolitan areas across the country, is ;grappling with an increase; in shootings and gang-related crimes. But the death of a child has intensified police efforts to solve Thursday's daylight shooting.

; Sat, 11 Nov 2023 04:22:01 +0800 Danger ahead: White Island volcano ruling could reshape adventure tourism in New Zealandhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/11/danger-ahead-white-island-volcano-ruling-could-reshape-adventure-tourism-in-new-zealand
;;2023-11-10T19:00:13Z;
;
;;White Island / Whakaari volcano erupts in 2019.
;

;White water rafting guide Hamish Watters stands in a garage, a 30-minute drive north of Wellington city, hosing down an inflatable raft and hanging lifejackets up to dry. The owner of Wellington Rafting has just taken five tourists down the swollen rapids of the Te Awa Kairangi/Hutt river.

;

;It has been a good morning for it – rain the previous day has lifted the river levels, giving customers a thrilling ride as they flew over gushing white water, hurling their rafts over hidden boulders and negotiating eddies near the gnarled banks.

;

;It can be a dangerous sport, with potential problems around every bend – from slippery rocks to flash flooding and landslides, or being turfed out of the boat – but Watters has his safety protocols down pat.

;

;“That stuff we can mitigate, by studying the environment … we find ourselves very, very connected to the elements,” Watters says.

; ;

;Customers are given a full run-down of the hazards before they go near the water and are prepared with a safety briefing “so they can 100% understand the risks involved”, Watters says. Before hopping into the rafts, customers gear up in hard hats, wetsuits and lifejackets.

;
;

;;Related: ;;White Island volcano eruption: Whakaari Management found guilty of 'astonishing' safety failures;

;
;

;Wellington Rafting is one of roughly 300 registered adventure tourism operators in New Zealand trying to strike a balance between offering exciting and potentially dangerous experiences while keeping their customers safe. Now, that responsibility will be even greater.

;

;The safety of adventure tourism has been pulled into sharper focus after a court ruling last week found the ;owners of Whakaari/White Island volcano guilty; of failing to adequately communicate the risks to visitors touring active volcano. In 2019, the volcano – a popular tourist destination 48km off the east coast of the North Island – ;erupted;, killing 22 people who were touring the crater and injuring 25.

;

;The disaster has led to tougher regulations requiring tourist operators to tell customers about serious risks before they embark on an adventure, but questions remain over the lasting impact of the tragedy on the wider adventure tourism industry, which forms a crucial part of New Zealand's NZ$40bn (£19.3bn) tourism sector.

; ;

;The Whakaari case and new regulations will have “enormous implications for all tourism businesses” and will extend far beyond adventure operators, says James Higham, a professor in tourism at Griffith University.

;

;“Any tourism business that takes place in environments that are potentially dangerous will need to take note of this and take steps towards knowing what their responsibilities are.”

;

;'Adventure capital of the world'

;

;New Zealand promotes itself as being the adventure capital of the world, with some New Zealanders responsible for creating and popularising some of the most famous adventure sports, including bungee jumping, zorbing and jet boating.

;

;Its adventure activities are so popular in part because of its record on safety. New Zealand is an outlier among other jurisdictions in requiring adventure activity operators to register their activities, thereby increasing the regulatory oversight of their business.

;

;“New Zealand has a global reputation in international tourism for being an advanced democracy, with legal systems and tourism policies in place and a safe destination that people visit to experience nature,” Higham says.

;

;Adventure tourism is not consistently tracked as a separate industry, but figures from 2011 show that 36% of international tourists that year took part in at least one adventure tourism activity while in New Zealand, contributing $4.1bn to the economy.

;

;“It's fair to say that we've become known internationally for the ability to get your blood pumping,” says Rebecca Ingram, the chief executive of Tourism Industry Aoteaora, the national body for tourism operators.

;

;“We're not the sort of destination where you lie by the pool – you're likely really motivated by getting into the outdoors and experiencing the environment, because that's what a holiday in New Zealand entails,” Ingram said.

;

;But the potential of natural risk looms large in New Zealand, an island nation that forms a spine over a tectonic fault line, and which is exposed to seismic, geothermal and meteorological hazards.

;

;Activities such as bungee jumping look enormously risky, when in actual fact they are “planned to the nth degree”, Higham says. Meanwhile, “going off into the national park on a beautiful spring day has a very low perceived risk but circumstances can change and those can be extremely challenging environments.”

;

;When Whakaari erupted, the world became aware of just how sudden and how devastating New Zealand's natural hazards could be. Some survivors of the eruption told a New Zealand court in July they were ;not informed of the potential dangers ;regarding a possible volcanic eruption until they were already on the volcano, and ;safety measures were lax;.

;

;Tougher regulations imposed

;

;In response to the tragedy and lack of proper communication over risk, the Labour government announced the introduction of tougher safety regulations on the industry to come into effect in April 2024, with a further sector-wide review earmarked for 2026.

;

;The incoming rules will heighten the onus on operators, as well as landowners, transport providers and tour companies, to communicate serious risks to customers before they buy a ticket. They will also be expected to consistently assess risk and work with agencies such as GNS, which monitors seismic activity, and meteorological services to provide day-to-day updates about hazards.

;

;The country's primary workplace and safety regulator, WorkSafe, will also receive expanded powers to shut down operators immediately and refuse registrations if there is evidence of imminent risk to people.

;

;Many operators already working to meet the requirements, says Ingram, and the organisation will work with the industry to get everyone up to speed by next year. But WorkSafe has not yet released “really important information” about how the rules will be applied, she adds, including the degree of responsibility on operators throughout the supply-chain and how natural hazards will be managed.

;

;Fundamentally, however, operators understand that maintaining a reputation as a safe country for adventure sports will keep the sector booming.

;

;“It is incredibly important that we take care of our manuhiri [guests] and that they leave the country with wonderful memories,” Ingram says.

;

;Rafting guide Watters believes operators will take the new rules in their stride. Managing ever-shifting environments, be they regulatory or natural, is part of the job.

;

;“Adventure guides are really used to being dynamic and adapting to new changes – that's our work all the time, and that's why we love it.”

; Sat, 11 Nov 2023 03:22:02 +0800 The Beatles set record 54-year gap between No 1 singles as Now and Then tops UK charthttps://www.theguardian.com/music/2023/nov/10/the-beatles-54-years-no-1-singles-now-and-then-uk-chart
;;2023-11-10T18:00:12Z;
;
;;The Beatles in 1969, the previous year they topped the UK chart.
;

;The Beatles have broken UK chart records as they return to No 1 with their “final” song together, Now and Then – their 18th chart-topper in total.

;

;Their 17th No 1 was The Ballad of John and Yoko in 1969, meaning they are now the artists with the longest gap between No 1 singles: 54 years, smashing the record set last year by Kate Bush when she reached the top with Running Up That Hill, 44 years after her No 1 with Wuthering Heights. Neither of the new songs the living members of the Beatles released in 1995 and 1996, Free as a Bird and Real Love, topped the charts.

;

;Now and Then, a midtempo ballad written by John Lennon in the late 1970s, uses his original demo recording combined with guitar lines recorded by the late George Harrison in 1994, plus new parts recorded by Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr. McCartney said of the song's chart-topping success: “It's mind boggling. It's blown my socks off. It's also a very emotional moment for me. I love it!”

; ;

;Now and Then's chart supremacy has been powered in part by a series of physical editions, including CD, cassette, 12in vinyl and four different coloured 7in vinyl versions, with the three non-black versions retailing at £17.99 each.

;

;Those unusually high prices were no deterrent for fans, many of whom queued at midnight on Friday last week to snap up copies. With 19,400 vinyl copies sold, it's the fastest selling vinyl single of the century, and its total physical sales of 38,000 were the biggest single week of physical sales since 2014, when X Factor winner Ben Haenow reached Christmas No 1 with Something I Need.

;

;Now and Then was also streamed more than 5 million times in the UK, by far the highest single week figure for any Beatles song. The Beatles' return was so anticipated that Now and Then actually reached the charts last Friday after being on release for just 10 hours before that week's cutoff, reaching No 42.

;

;The band extend their record as the British artist with the most No 1 singles, with Official Charts Company chief executive Martin Talbot saying: “If there were ever any doubts that the Beatles are the greatest band of all time, they have surely consigned them to history this week.”

;

;They will need to find a fair bit more in the vaults if they want to beat Elvis Presley, who has 21 No 1s, though Peter Jackson, who directed Now and Then's music video, has said it's not beyond the realms of possibility. “We can take a performance from [Jackson's documentary film] Get Back, separate John and George, and then have Paul and Ringo add a chorus or harmonies,” he told the Sunday Times this week. “You might end up with a decent song but I haven't had conversations with Paul about that. It's fanboy stuff but certainly conceivable.”

;
;

;;Related: ;;The Beatles: Now and Then review – 'final' song is a poignant act of closure;

;
;

;The album chart meanwhile hosted the return of other musical legends, with Cliff Richard scoring his 48th Top 10 album with Cliff With Strings – My Kinda Life at No 5, Johnny Marr getting a fifth solo Top 10 album with best-of compilation Spirit Power at No 7, and Van Morrison getting a 44th Top 40 album with Accentuate the Positive at No 39.

;

;Bucking the trend for new albums to swiftly drop down the charts, the Rolling Stones earn a third week in the Top Five with Hackney Diamonds. Oasis are the highest new entry at No 2 with a reissue of B-sides compilation The Masterplan ahead of K-pop star Jung Kook at No 3, while Taylor Swift's re-recorded version of 1989 remains at No 1 for a second week.

;

;Swift was deposed by the Beatles in the singles chart, her song Is It Over Now dropping to No 3. Prada, a remix of D-Block Europe and Raye's song Ferrari Horses made by producer Cassö on his Swansea University laptop, spends a ninth week in the Top 5 at No 2, while Tate McRae and Tyla each return to the Top 5.

;The suspect is the son of Sam Haskell, a former talent agent and head of worldwide head of television at William Morris, now known as the William Morris Endeavor Agency, who represented A-list stars including Dolly Parton, George Clooney, Whoopi Goldberg and King Charles's brother, Prince Edward.

;The prime minister's spokesperson said on Friday that an “ongoing internal process” within No 10 into the article was taking place and that there were no updates on what might happen to Braverman.

;

;However, it is understood that even if Sunak has already decided to sack Braverman for what was a flagrant challenge to his authority, this will not happen until next week at the earliest, given the sensitivities of this weekend.

;

;A number of right-leaning groups have pledged to stage counter-protests. If there are clashes, the rhetoric of Braverman could be under scrutiny as to whether it might have inflamed tensions.

;

;“Our collective focus working with the Home Office and other colleagues in government now is on ensuring that remembrance events this weekend are protected from disruption and that veterans and those gathering to mark Remembrance Sunday and in the Jewish community do not face unacceptable intimidation,” Sunak's spokesperson said.

;

;Saying that the prime minister viewed both the pro-Palestine protest and any counter-demonstrations as disrespectful, the spokesperson would not say if Sunak and Braverman had spoken since the Times article was published, saying there would not be a “running commentary” on the inquiry process.

;

;There is, nonetheless, considerable anger within No 10 at the fact Braverman's article ran without changes ordered by Sunak's team, with increasingly few of her fellow ministers willing to endorse her argument that police tend to be softer on leftwing protesters than those from the right.

;

;There is also upset at Braverman's comparison of pro-Palestine activists to marchers in Northern Ireland, largely unionists, with whom the Conservatives are generally allied.

;A number of right-leaning Tory backbenchers have spoken out in favour of Braverman, with Sunak facing a potentially significant internal row if she is sacked.

;Asked on Friday whether he endorsed the sentiments, Hunt, the chancellor, said: “As many other cabinet ministers have said, the words that she used are not words that I myself would have used. ;Sunak's spokesperson hinted that the prime minister also took a different view to Braverman. Asked whether he agreed with the home secretary, given Sunak had expressed very different sentiments, she said: “You have the prime minister's words on this issue.”

;It adds to a tumultuous week for Braverman. who is facing growing criticism over her language over both policing and homelessness, which she has separately ;described as a “lifestyle choice”;.

;As Sunak considers Braverman's fate, a growing number of ministers are either distancing themselves from her language or openly criticising it.
